results.title: Art, people, feelings
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford Film Productions, Pyramid Films and Paul Burnford
results.brief_description: The relationship between human emotions and the art created is illustrated by a selection of artistic works which span all periods of history and a variety of subjects. Shows ways in which artists use many materials and methods to translate their personal feelings into visual forms: murals, landscapes, portraits, posters, billboards, abstract paintings, cartoons, pop art, sculpture and motion pictures. Suitable for secondary level years 7-12.

results.title: Art to the people
results.brief_description: Shows the work of the process engravers and the printers who produce each year the calendar of reproductions of wining entries in the Dunlop Art Contest. The film illustrates all stages in the production of the calendar from the photographing of the original material by the process engraver to the final wrapping of the printed article. The film also illustrates the opportunities for apprenticeship in the printing industry.

results.title: Art survives the times
results.brief_description: A record of art life in France. Leading artists such as Matisse, Picasso, Ultrillo and the sculptors, Roualt, Laurens and Janniot, are shown at work. The architects, Le Corbusier and Perret, also display plans for homes and cities. No other credits available.

results.title: Art since pop
results.brief_description: A general survey of the major developments in US painting and sculpture in the 70’s, following the emergence of Pop Art. Part 1 discusses hard-edge painting, minimalism, shaped canvasses, industrial processes, environmental sculptures and earthworks. It features the work of painters Barnet Newman, Ellsworth Kelly, Mark Rothko, Charles Hinman, Frank Stella and Kenneth Noland, and of sculptors Donald Judd and Christo. Part 2 concentrates on Op art and its interest in illusions of motion, kinetic art, neon and fluorescent art, video art, happenings, holograms and lasers.

results.title: Art of the sixties
results.creator_credit: Merrill Brockway, Bailey Film Productions and WCBS-TV
results.brief_description: This film documents the major directions in modern American art during the first seven years of the 1960’s. The keynote is that the artist has expanded the realm of art from the two-dimensional picture frame, climaxed by the artists of the 40’s and early 50’s, merged colour with sculpture, and sought out modern media to produce the characteristic wide spectrum of interests, ideas and products in the art of our time. The works of about 15 artists are represented, including George Segal’s life-size plaster representational figures, Klaus Oldenburg’s monumental Pop works, Donald Judd’s hard-edge two and three-dimensional paintings and Robert Rauschenberg’s three-dimensional objects in motion. The narrator discusses the collaboration between the artist and the modern industrial craftsman in certain complex works. The interesting focus on environmental art which has brought art beyond the third dimension is exemplified by several artists working together on “happenings”; by the sound and motion production models for the future by Len Lye, and by Les Levine’s work with Mylar, light and air. Narrated by Leonard Harris. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Art of the Persian carpet
results.brief_description: Depicts the entire process of creating Persian carpets, from preparing and dyeing the wool, through the intricate symbolic design patterns, to the complex handwork where young weavers tie up to three million knots to complete one carpet. Shows the remote Indian tribes who weave the finest carpets. Suitable for Upper Secondary students.

results.title: Art of hand screen printing
results.creator_credit: Stanley Murphy, Orion Pictures Corporation and Albert Lane
results.brief_description: The evolution of hand printed silk from the designer’s original sketch, taken from nature, through the many processes until the fabric is completed. Shows in detail the transfer of the photographic copy to the screen, mixing of dyes and the steam treating of the fabric.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stanley Murphy, Orion Pictures Corporation and Albert Lane

results.title: Art of age
results.creator_credit: Stanley Hawes, New South Wales Film Corporation and David E. Barrow
results.brief_description: Four elderly people reflect on the possibilities of maintaining a fulfilling and productive life into old age. They all tell of there involvement with community groups and of the way they teach others their talents.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Stanley Hawes, New South Wales Film Corporation and David E. Barrow

results.title: Art maps
results.creator_credit: Neville Stanley, Jeff Spencer and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Chalkface”.
Chalkface co-editor, Piri White, introduces the work of teachers and students at Richmond Primary School in linking art across the curriculum. The theme of the program is “monsters and things are not always what they seem”

results.title: Art in the western world
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Treasures from the National Gallery of Art in Washington are used to present the development of Western art from the thirteenth century. The film opens with a discussion of Byzantine and early Italian painting and explains the gradual development of realism during the Renaissance. The work of famous artists such as Velasquez, Rembrandt, Van Eyck and Goya illustrate the development of art up to the nineteenth century. The film concludes with examples of French Impressionism and Post Impressionism.
